message.content: We refer to Mayo Clinic and Harvard Health Publishing for help. The symptoms suggest panic attacks and anxiety disorder, which can be treated with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as fluoxetine. D-dimer is not indicated as there are no signs of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Echocardiography is not indicated as the patient has no abnormal findings on physical examination and normal cardiac enzymes. Lorazepam can provide short-term relief but does not address the underlying anxiety disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of panic attacks, which are not related to cardiac issues. Prescribing fluoxetine, an SSRI, can help manage the anxiety and prevent future panic attacks. Echocardiography and D-dimer measurement are not necessary as cardiac issues and pulmonary embolism are not likely causes. Lorazepam may provide short-term relief but is not a long-term solution.

D-dimer measurement is used to rule out pulmonary embolism, which is not a likely cause of the patient’s symptoms. Echocardiography is not necessary unless there are specific indications. Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine that may provide temporary symptomatic relief, but is not a long-term solution.
